author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
I have many thoughts but I would probably lead with this. You are likely learning what’s “correct” on the internet, having been in the game for a minute I can tell you that 90% of what you are reading is wrong, or incomplete or misses the point

Your clients however will be your greatest teachers. I learn more every year than the last, and I’m 31 years into record life and 23’in mastering

Clients understand music intuitively, they are reaching for something bigger than LUFS, and tonal balance curves. Keep an open ear, write short emails and you’ll keep learning

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think it's a blessing to get feedback about how you're fucking up. True, it's challenging at first, but it's the fastest way to building a good intuition and make the best moves.

My last girlfriend was very vocal about where she thought my shortcomings were. Where I was undeveloped and where I was not meeting her expectations. The kind of stuff that might make some people crumple under the pressure. While that could be a little exhausting at times I was happy to have it and accepted it in the positive spirit in which it was given. 

If you're lucky enough to get true signals about things then hold onto them tight because that's the path to positive growth.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Hey @Gerhard Westphalen I don’t have time to read the replies so a quick summary of how I do it, sorry if it’s repeating 

1) Don’t take the limiter off, on many modern projects the music will be unrecognizable without it and it's what the artist approved. I typically reduce the limiting amount around 2dB, sometimes more sometimes less. I’ll also re balance clipper and limiter relationships

2) Don’t do any pre-emptive processing with the exceptions perhaps of paying a little extra care if it’s a project with heavy sibilance. Don’t mono the bass, don’t change the EQ etc 

3) Make a single WAV file of each side, and a set of timing notes that show where each track starts and the length so the cutting engineer can place the track banding / markers

4) I like to highlight anomalies that may present a challenge for cutter but it’s not necessary

author: LAPhill
content:
"Honor the intent of the feedback" being the crucial part of maturing in your craft. Reading between the lines of the feedback. "This chorus needs to hit harder, turn up the crash on the downbeat" might actually mean that the 4 bars leading up to it are too big, masking the lift you should be feeling, or there's a synth pad hanging over the bar and making things mushy. The client can identify where it's not working, but not so often why. And that comes with reps and an open mind. 

But also sometimes you just need to turn up the fucking crash.

author: hebakadry
content: Hey, pretty stoked about this new plugin.  Safe to say there hasn’t been much innovation in the lathe world until this plugin came around…was checking it out a bit in the beta testing phase…for those who aren’t cutting engineers the reference edition is absolutely amazing.  You can get a general sense of how your master will sound to cut and even audition various turntables and cartridges to see how it could sound.  Better language and tools when you’re communicating with your cutting engineer as well.  It also has an amazing visual emulation so you can actually see what’s going on with your grooves.  This is such a special plugin…i don’t get behind a lot of stuff but this is pretty game changing, esp for mastering engineers that don’t cut but actually care about the translation to LP. It was developed with Helmut Erler who was at Dubplates for many years…really amazing dude and friend of mine.  He's cut some really important techno records.  I think the visualization of the cutter head and the grooves will start to make sense to a lot of people that are a bit in the dark about cutting and modulation and how program material can really affect how things sound ultimately…also how you process your master esp when it goes to plants that do in house cuts that are a bit on the safe/boring side.  You can get ahead and provide a master that counteracts some of the wide processing moves they make to avoid distortion at all cost.  Also send your client a ref of what your cut could sound esp when people push back on super long programs that don't translate well https://www.tokyodawn.net/tdr-simulathe-ref/

author: cian riordan
content: I used to try and think about what sort of sonics the ME would bring to the mixes. If there was a certain vibe to the record, try and go with someone that had experience with that aesthetic and let them lean into 'their' sound. Over the years it became somewhat exhausting to have to go back and forth with MEs doing revisions and tweaking. There was a certain point where I felt I had to QC every revision that came back and it was just too much with multiple projects swimming around. When I started using Chris @ Sterling, that process just went away. Things came back enhanced, never modified... if that makes sense. Plus I never had any issues with clicks and pops... so I could literally just do a quick check (maybe verse/chorus) to make sure things add up and move on -- trust the process. Same w/ using @Nomograph Mastering... it ends up being less work for me, not more -- and the end product ends up sounding better while retaining the original intent of the mixes.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Below I am sharing something that I send to my mastering clients when they inquire about targeting LUFS levels for streaming services. I hope it is helpful to some readers. Discussion is welcome.


Regarding mastering to streaming LUFS loudness normalization targets, i.e. -14 LUFS - I do not recommend trying to do that. I know it's discussed all over the web, but in reality very few people actually do it. To test this, try turning loudness matching off in Spotify settings, then check out the tracks listed under "New Releases" and see if you can find material that's not mastered to modern loudness for it's genre. You will probably find little to none. Here's why people aren't doing it:

1 - In the real world, loudness normalization is not always engaged. For example, Spotify Web Player and Spotify apps integrated into third-party devices (such as speakers and TVs) do not have loudness normalization. YouTube is normalized but "YouTube Music" is not normalized. Apple Music's web player is not normalized. With normalization off, your -14 LUFS track will sound much softer than most other tracks.

2- Even with loudness normalization turned on, many people have reported that their -14 LUFS masters sound quieter than other tracks in playlists.

3 - Some streaming services have different loudness targets (Apple's is -16) and there's no guarantee they won't change their loudness targets again in the future. For example, Spotify lowered their loudness target by 3dB in 2017, then in 2021 they switched measurement from ReplayGain to LUFS. Also, in Spotify Premium app settings you find 3 different loudness settings; "Quiet, Normal, and Loud". Now AES is recommending that all music streaming services switch to -16 LUFS. It's a moving target. 

4 - Some people suggest making multiple masters at different levels. But digital aggregators (CD Baby, etc.) generally do not allow more than one version of each song, so you'd have to make separate paid submissions.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Do it all the time but it’s a less effective place to shape a record than in mixing. If someone has a vision for how it should or could sound I think it’s generally more effective to express that in mixing (in mastering brightening the vocal brings out the snare, push the kick brings out bass notes etc etc). Sure we have cool tricks and RX etc but why not just mix the record?

author: Rollmottle
content:
nah, fuck -1 or -2. theoretically the lower the ceiling, the less risk there is of intersample peaks happening upon conversion to MP3 or some other lossless format streamers use to stream audio to your device. even if there are ISP's, they usually light up a meter but are inaudible. i live at -0.5db for most everything. sometimes i'll go to -0.3db if it's something that is pop oriented (this is where i landed for @thejadenmejia's single for example). i think a lot of the panic about it is overblown. in the real world, clients like their shit loud.

as far as distro goes, i know some are starting to accept higher res files or even accepting multiple files. my deliverables have always been 96/24 and 44/16. I've recently started including 44/24's. i've always discouraged submitting anything other than 44/16 because who knows what some of these services are doing with SRC and dither, but i think with the advent of high res and lossless delivery, you are well-advised to submit the higher bit-rate files nowadays. all that said, with something like 44/24 you are probably pretty safe from getting your shit munched down-funnel.

This track ended up being a very very dynamic mix. Very loud choruses and very quiet verses. They made the request that I use 2 or more really nice compressors to help bring it all together (before I even heard the track). 

I still did not use any "compressors". Though, level automation was my friend - automated intro, verses and bridges up much close to the choruses. 

I didn't disclose the moves I made, and I just said "Let me know if this does the trick" and they were as happy as two compressors spreading the load.

author: Victor Garcia
content:
100% red flag. I experienced here a similar situation with what I think it is the best plant here in Spain. Of course they don’t cut in house but they send to cut to a very good engineer in Europe outside Spain. A VERY good decision for their business. I recommend all my clients to hire them because the results have been always super good. But… one day I got a PDF from the client asking if my masters had been through that PDF specifics. And this PDF was made by the spanish plant.
I just called the plant asking if that pdf was done by their cutting engineer of choice and they told me it wasn’t.
It was just a guide made by them they send always to their clients just “in case”. 
We chat for a while (so friendly and honestly) and told them if they could talk directly to their cutting engineer and ask for her/his opinion about that pdf.
One day later they just called me to say that will not send it again because the cutting eng said it was a non sense.
I’m happy with it because it was all done so friendly (both ways) for the sake of the art.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Yes -- definitely save as montage every single time I ship a file, and then before I do any adjusting on a revision. So previous pass is kept as is.

It depends on how I name it. Like you said, any system that makes sense to you and is granular enough to track all files shipped will work. These days, with albums very often coming in slow dripped as singles, and massive amounts of changes last minute (it's how the game is), it pays to be very organized. I'll even go so far as to name things descriptively if it makes sense for the project (brighter, heavier, etc etc), or by date, whatever. 

But the real work of mastering every day is very messy, and you have to have a good way to track everything.

Granted, I'm more of a "creative" type from my experience than a very in the weeds structured type (neither right or wrong), so my system works for me. I can always get exactly back to what was shipped, montage open within under a minute for sure which helps creative flow.

My 2 cents -- I'd totally do away with the initial rough master. Think of it from the client side. Rough master says "hey give me validation" and puts the onus on them to listen. Every interaction incurs a cost. Sending just the master, exactly as you hear it and owning it, works so much better in my experience (believe me, I've been the guy to send options before back in the day). Ruairi is exactly right on this

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Oh man. I’ve had this happen to me twice. With BIG mastering guys. Greg Calbi mastered a mix of mine once and it came back STUPID hot, distorted, unreasonable. We ended up getting it there, but it can be disheartening. 

My approach is always contingent on my relationship with the artist. How much do they trust you, how much do you want to continue working with them, etc. @Rollmottle is always great with his words, and that kind of approach is key to get the conversation started. I also find that having an alternative master for the artist to listen to is helpful. Rather than explaining what’s wrong, just being able to say “I think this direction might serve the music better…” 

That being said, if the artist is asking their friend to master it, you might end up being the most professional person involved in the record. And you can see that as a responsibility, or an excuse to stfu and move on. If you’re proud of the mix you can always post THAT version on your platforms. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

author: Railtown Mastering
content:
100% get that spark of excitement. Bit different than the lightning in a bottle thing that can happen when you’re sitting in the room, but it still scratches the itch for me. Definitely have moments where I’m like, man, I can’t believe I get to be a part of this.

I came from a background in recording and mixing, which really helped when I transitioned into mastering. I never actively promoted all three since my goal was always to master full-time, but for a while, I did a bit of everything with existing clients to make ends meet. Now, I’m lucky to be so busy with mastering that I don’t even have time to consider other work. And while I could probably still pull off a passable mix, my friends who do it every day would do a much better job. I think there’s immense value in eventually specializing and putting all your energy into one place.

Having said that, everyone’s path looks different, and there’s no single right way to get where you want to go. For me, specializing and putting all my energy into mastering was the right move, but I know plenty of people who thrive wearing multiple hats. I think the key is figuring out what excites you most and what you’re best at, and leaning into that.

author: eschirtz
content:
I hear you Ruairi, and ultimately you gotta make your own call on this. 

But I just wanna reassure you that our business is built around serving your type of workflow. Even if 99% of users don't give a shit about the perfect playback, we do. That's why we have that "lossless" switch. We'll never switch to AAC due to bandwidth issues.

The "constant upgrades" are often due to the ever changing landscape of browsers. Each client is often on a different browser, different device and different internet connection. It's our job to understand that landscape and push fixes to ensure we get perfect playback across all environments. 

That's part of the reason we built the iOS app, to be able to provide a more consistent playback experience when browsers themselves are the limiting factor, and so that clients can listen offline to take the network out of the equation. But I totally understand that you can't really ask a client to install another app on their iPhone. 

To my knowledge, Samply is still the only platform that lets clients stream full resolution lossless AND gapless track transitions in a browser. It's a really tough engineering challenge, but ultimately the backbone of our entire business. We're committed to continuing to solve this problem and evolve with the technology available.

author: Edsel Holden
content:
I will share words that are not mine (these words belong to @Nomograph Mastering )

Context is important here. This is an email that Nomogrpah wrote back to a client that said "Hey I love the master so much but I am a bit worried about how much it might get turned down ?" or something to that effect 

Response was 

"Glad you are feeling the master!

Re the level thing that is a complicated question. A few thoughts

Not everyone has loudness normalization turned on. It also doesn’t exist on Smart TVs, many streaming web interfaces etc

The different services all have different level norm targets (and even different settings within just Spotify) - and they change pretty regularly

In terms of absolute level when normalization is active what matters is arrangement (dense mixes sound quieter than sparse/spacious mixes), EQ (bright/mid range forward mixes sound louder than dark) and distortion levels (clipped/distorted mixes feel perceptually louder than clean). If I make a master a dB louder in mastering using just limiting for example, they just turn it down a dB more when it’s level normed.

So what does all of this mean? It means that every song has sweet spot where the EQ/tone, the arrangement and the overall clipping/limiting level works best and communicates the intent. That’s what we aim for.

You can use a site like loudnesspenalty.com to see what will happen but it will just drive you crazy and the only real way to meaningfully alter the result is to change the arrangement/mix or overall EQ a lot. On release day you can find 1000 records that are louder than yours if you want to.

If being the loudest is the intent - game everything listed above and you can “win”. If doing your unique thing and communicating a song and a performance is the goal then I think you are there!"

(posted with Nomographs permission)

author: Rollmottle
content:
1. Pull in all pre-masters into one session. Name all regions and order it as intended. 
2. Initial pre-master listen to gain the material to be generally the same RMS (material dependent of course) so that it hits my analog chain at a consistent level....draw in any obviously needed volume automation. 
3. Start mastering....which for me is two steps...the actual deep pre-master listen to understand what the track may need. It is as this stage where I'll address any technical issues (pre-analog processing, RX work, additional automation refinement, etc.). Then comes the actual master processing step and the subsequent master capture.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. I immediately change the frequency graph to *Log* or *Extended Log*. This allows me to see the low-end and midrange with more resolution. It's the same reason most EQ graphs keep the octaves evenly spaced so that 50% of your freq graph isn't 10kHz and up. It gives you more resolution for the notes in the lower octaves.

As for FFT size or window shape, I never change it, but as Ruairi alluded to it requires an understanding of the physical limitations of FFT's. 

In short if you want very fine frequency information displayed you can change the window size and lose rhythmic information. But it you want very precise rhythmic visualization you have to sacrifice how much frequency information the FFT can display. So the ideal setting ultimately depends on what problem you're trying to solve.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Keep in mind I’m still very new to mastering compared to most here, but this has happened several times already to me.

I’d do it on goodwill. Ideally your workflow and back end systems would make this a very small lift. Unless it’s something wild, better to have the client have a wonderful experience, keep their momentum, don’t introduce doubt, double down on their confidence, etc.

I’m assuming it would be something like making sure the levels and overall tone are right if you’ve already mastered them all and they are in the same ballpark, but feel free to tell me if I’m wrong.

Also “cohesion” is massively overrated to me anyway, I much prefer a creatively interesting and varied listening experience if the music calls for it as long as we are not having wild level or EQ swings or something (sometimes it calls for cohesion to have the best listening experience IMO, so know that too!). 

I’ve had multiple instances where an artist’s new “single” release includes their several past singles I’ve mastered too. They didn’t tell me they were doing that, and I mastered each totally alone, just based on the song and their vision. And to be honest those collections sounded totally fine every time as a group of singles, mastered alone.

All that said, I’d definitely politely educate them on what it exactly entails so it doesn’t happen again in future, and so they can take it into account creatively.

But of course where you are in your career, the relationship with this client, etc all plays into this. Someone like @Nomograph Mastering could very well see this very differently than me

author: Berlin
content:
I would suggest not changing the program material/main master too much and just preparing the sides, delivering one file per side, along with the PQ/Cut sheets with the track marker times (again one cut sheet per side), doing the QC listen down after export, and delivering with your approval.

I think backing off the limiter is sometimes OK, but very program material dependent. Yanking the limiter off a hot pop master might change things too much, for example.

Additionally, whoever is cutting the lacquer, will likely be doing their own adjustments as they see fit.. so if you are concerned about it translating properly, I would get with a lacquer engineer that you know and trust so you can have a dialogue about it, if needed.

That being said, in my experience, great sounding projects/masters will sound good on vinyl if the cutting engineer knows what they are doing… no matter how much you try to help with the PreMaster.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
First of all Edsel, congrats!! Sounds like you crushed it. Warms my heart to see others in here succeeding.

I’m extremely green (just going on like 5 months mastering full time), and was sort of interested that you thought it was perhaps not cool to use the limited ref? I’m getting similar stuff (limited, heated ref, unlimited), and honestly I find I’m using the ref certainly some of the time and working from there. Sometimes there is just magic there, and while my chain may be “better” it’s also just different, especially when I can tell people are mixing into that ref chain.

I guess I just mention because going into my new “role” in mastering I made a very conscious decision to only operate on a binary: is what I’m doing making the record feel better to me or not? Is it becoming more of what it wants to be?

And throw out any notions of what I felt I “should” be doing.

In some ways being very new has given me a great creative armor, I am not afraid to lose and therefore do not feel bad or something if the ref is a better starting point than my chain or if I am doing very little.

I am fascinated in your perspective as someone who is a pros pro but in between where I am and where Ruairi is.

I’ll land the plane here…it seems like the fact that this song was “above your pay grade” sort of played into the fact that you were maybe seeking Ruairi’s approval to use that limited ref?

Do you think you would have approached using the ref any differently if you knew it was just some kid in a bedroom, or would you have still trusted that it was still the move to use it?

I ask myself this stuff a lot, since I’d like to think I’m always doing exactly what is right for the song, but of course many factors play into our decision making (insecurity, relationships, fear of losing a project, etc)

Sorry for the rant, but your story was very inspiring! Happy for you!!

author: Ross Fortune
content:
On that note, can't remember where I found this but a related piano recipe from Michael Brauer. Hoping he hasn't trademarked this one so the Discord doesn't get shut down.



"Remember the early Elton John records? Remember how his piano shimmered? At mediasound we loved that sound so a lot of us were always playing around with getting different versions of it. No lacquered hammers, no Dolby A off, just a combination of compression and EQ.


I only recorded Luther's voice, may he rest in peace, on that song along with "searching" and then mixed both. Luther was on a whole other level of singers. He walked into that session and listened to the song in the control room once, then he walked out into the studio with the lyric sheet in his hand. What you hear on"Glow of Love" and "searching" is his first fun down reading the lyrics from a yellow pad. No punches.


The piano sound you’re referring to is probably the same one that I did for Vandross on the “Never too much” song.


Ok, this is how you do it.

1. First insert an LA3A or LA2A (depending on the version of sound you’re going after) across the stereo piano tracks. The LA2A is good if the song is slow and the chords are quarter notes. The LA3A is good if the chords are faster with a harder attack like in “never too much”. Bang those meters and 
2. out of the compressor go into a couple of pultecs and push up..way up the 3 or 5 k on the low end and the 8 or 10 k on the high end. Don’t be safe. 
3. Now go to the desk EQ and start clearing out some of the muddiness and EQ up the remaining mids so that it just shimmers like a baby. 
4. When it’s done right, you can hear the harmonics riding up during each sustain.  
5. I remember hearing that song on the radio and man that piano was making me feel good all over. Sounds pretty simple when you know how to do it right?”

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Gonna check it after I am wrapped for the day! Thanks for sharing.

Another thing I think about a lot, and I believe posted about it before, was an old Bill Evans documentary where he touched on how to learn to improvise/etc...and his main principle was to essentially "play at your level", and accept that's where you are. So instead of playing a bunch of fast notes...play only a few very slowly and intentionally...his theory was that it will sound and feel the most authentic that way.

In a mastering context, I think about just taking the song was far as I can at my current moment...like I may note be a Ruairi or Dale or Rollmottle but I can still do things that I think sound good and add to the record. It may not be as far as I can go in a year, or 10 but it still can read very musical and cared-for! But it takes a lot of...shall we say self-reflection to accept that I'm not where I can be yet and live with it you know? Instead of trying to force something on a record that doesn't need it

author: Conah Tucker
content:
Howdy folks! Started running some tests for the tiktok normalisation but I've found an engineer that's already run some tests and discovered a fair bit.

Quick notes:
Web tiktok and mobile tiktok process audio differently: 
- Web tiktok has a -1db ceiling. 
- Mobile tiktok compress the audio. This engineer reckons its a soft knee comp at -12, 50.1 ratio, fast attack.

I'm still running some loudness tests. Heavy compression at -12 seems a little too murderous to me.

author: Rollmottle
content: Circling back to double click on a point that's buried in here...the goal of reference tracks is to have stable points of reference you KNOW. Find tracks you think are "bright" or "dark" or "punchy" or "clear" or "vague" or "big" or "bassy" or whatever so you know what those things feel like for you, in your room and on your speakers. Imprint all that onto your brain and eventually you develop an intuition for where your target is as you listen, not only in your room, but anywhere.

author: Rollmottle
content:
Been reflecting on the discussion here...

I just don’t subscribe to the idea that loud = bad. There’s a whole school of the online mastering discourse that holds this belief and it strikes me as disconnected from the mainstream. It presupposes that loudness comes at significant cost to the material in some way — which way? Emotional? technical? artistic?  Or that all material should be dynamic…which is, of course, not true. 

As Noah was getting at, some of my most vivid memories of live music both as a performer and as an audience member exist BECAUSE they were loud as fuck. Loud is in our DNA. There’s a visceral, tactile and emotional response to loud. Even if we’re talking about a “quiet” or more dynamic record, people will turn it up so they can feel it.

Good loud is within everybody’s grasp in 2025 and I love being able to make loud records louder, with minimal, if any, trade off. If I can deliver an appropriately loud master given the material with little compromise, I will. That’s exciting to me and not a bummer. It's what the vast majority of my clients are looking for. Of course if the record doesn’t call for loud, we don’t make it loud. But, I also don’t think excessive loudness is what’s making or breaking records.

Of course there was always an arbitrary deadline for the next day

author: Rollmottle
content: Samply is a purpose-built tool for audio professionals that allows me to provide clients (Artists, Mixers, etc) a way to experience their record as they and their audience would consume it via a custom player. The player is fully sharable,  includes artwork and track titles, etc. Feels like a private Spotify for somebody and doesn't require them to install or download anything and helps to make their record feel "done." Dropbox or a link to a .zip can't do this.

author: Gerhard Westphalen

author: Rollmottle
content:
I don't put a form in front of my clients. It's just not how I think about their engagement with me. I'm a person and accessible, not a black box to have data submitted to. I get the motivation to do it, but I'd rather have a conversation with my clients than put something in between me and them, especially as the first touchpoint. I deliver back in the sample rate and bit depth I received the mixes in and that usually works for most of the time since I am working with a lot of indie artists. As @Edsel Holden says, if they need other formats, they'll ask for it. As you grow, I think it becomes even less useful if you start working with bigger teams and labels.

Your problem could be solved simply by asking them which service they'll use to digitally distribute.

author: Berlin
content:
I have also forgone the form and scheduling tool since summer.. It was helpful for a season for me, but mostly for me honing my work flow. 
Now we are back to emails forward facing (much because of the advice from so many of you - even killing the contact form on my website- raw email only) and using notion on the backend as a PM tool. I also have Merv working with me now as PM and we are 1 month in and I might be the happiest I’ve ever been with my workflow. 

Keeping things all conversational and casual/friendly with clients has been wonderful, for clients and myself.

author: Josh Bowman

author: Berlin
content: Digital "Vinyl Premasters" where an ME might mono sum the low end or not use a limiter, or do some of those types of "vinyl master" tricks, are honestly getting into the minutia and we are talking about 1-2% gains in the final result.. It should be mentioned also that the cutting engineer will also have their own cutting mastering chain of various outboard units that are going to try and catch some of those "issues" that might be presented. Best practice, and others might disagree with me, in my house is to prepare the vinyl sides and a PQ sheet, QC the export, and ship it. Don't fuck with an approved master/project too much. - Partner with a great lacquer engineer, and the Master will be dope.

author: Berlin
content: That being said, when starting out, working with other clients that are likely also starting out, the Delta between mix and master tends to be greater. - Further down the road, the delta gets smaller and smaller, more often that not.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
In the real world basically everything that people care about has massive amounts of limiting. I get that the Bob Katzs and Ian Shepherds dominate the tenor of the online conversation but their effect on popular music is the inverse.

Re 1. Masterer same as cutter - they are not gonna be coming here for advice and we don't need to teach them anything

Re 2. Digital and cutting engineer working together happens sometimes but is often out of our control. Again in the real world the vinyl deadline is always the most pressing, and there is no way artists or labels will listen to the files prepared for cutting or understand the tradeoffs - that's why they pay us the medium bucks. I have had several great relationships with cutitng engineers over the years, and will always use my guy if I can. But often it's a black box and I won't even get test pressings.

Why make a vinyl? Becuase it's one of the only ways artists can sustain these days, becuase it's a wonderful artifact and because it's romantic.

Re your "don't care about the cut's sound" comment ... we can do better than that level of conversation here. I've shipped a set of vinyl Masters every day this week, two today. have a second set of test pressings arriving today for a project with issues. This shit is serious as heart attack for me

author: Øra Mastering
content:
Like many have writen here, I also make sure my clients are happy (if not thrilled) about their masters before I send the invoice. You have discussed why this is good for the clients experience, but I have noticed how my subconscious attitude for the project changes the few times people have insisted paying in front of the project. 

Usually I have a huge motivation on moving a project along super quick and making sure to have a fast turnaround - the faster I respond and make them happy about their music = payday, both in positive feedback and 💵. But there is really no pressure since I have only received files, they haven’t payed me anything. If the client has payed, I either find myself slacking bc it’s already payed OR stressing out big time bc they have payed and I feel a huge pressure on not f*cking up the project and the smooth creative process goes out the window. My brain works better with a carrot then a stick.

That’s why I have found I do my best and fastest work when invoicing after masters are approved. I am sure other ME’s brains are wired the other way around.

author: Øra Mastering
content: I work both hybrid and itb. When working hybrid, I try to keep the same settings for a whole album and do eq, de-essing and level automation pre analog if needed (on individual tracks). On some albums, for me, there is no way around tweaking analog settings per track, but I try to avoid it. When printing the album I use the print-time to casually listen to the album from start to finish to catch stuff I would like to adjust (one track lacks impact ect.). Final limiter is always post analog print and I do not print hot. This makes revisions a breeze 97% of the time, unless there is a new mix of course. Also easy to back of a limiter without reprinting if the client wants more dynamics or I want a more dynamic vinyl pre-master. Hope that made sense.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I'm no Ruairi, but I think about this a lot too, interested in your perspective. The only thing I've ever been able to come up with is "I like it". Of course I do my best to take the vision of the project into consideration, where it is and the potential it has to go further...but it truly and always comes down to just asking myself "am I connecting emotionally, and do I like the music better as a listener than before".

On some level, we can only be what we are, if that makes sense. I can't master as well as I will be able to in a year, 5 years, 10 years. But I just do the best I can, when I feel connected to the record, it's done.

Have had quite a bit of stuff come recently, had to get it out quick. I also specifically practice doing very short masters (not for a client, just practice)...I find this lets me know where I am. Almost always just keeping on tweaking hurts the music, our objectivity, etc. Some of my favorite ones I've done were done in 10 minutes. And not because I rushed, because I just trusted my intuition. And I hope this doesn't come off as arrogant/etc but I deeply believe in my taste and what I like. I never question it. Luckily, people seem to agree with me so far. But unless you have that trust in yourself and are willing to put it on the line, not sure how anyone could really do high, high level work like Ruairi is (feel free to push back on this).

And sometimes, a "bold move" is to barely do anything. That takes a lot of trust and belief too.

 My issues almost always lie in me not being able to quite get it where I want to go. That's hard. But never about where it should go, if that makes sense. Sometimes I may be wrong, or people disagree creatively, which is great! That's information we can use to bring their vision to life more accurately.

One of my favorite coach speak/quote things from my football days was "you don't rise to the occasion, you default to your level of training". I find it's true. 

Thoughts on how you approach that?

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: Rollmottle
content:
This is a tough one. Couple routes I see. Depends on the relationships and how much it matters in the grand scheme:

1. Flip the burger and do the best you can with what you've got.
2. Tell your buddy to do better and what to fix to ensure the best outcome.
3. Bite a big bullet and fix it yourself.
4. Split the difference with your buddy. Tell him to prep stems and do a stem master so you can have access to "fix" some of it.

Would all depend on how much the relationship with the artist matters, if the song rips but the production is getting in the way, end goal etc.

I have done 1,2 and 4 to varying degrees. I'd probably start with 2 though and see what happens.

author: spectrummasters
content:
......well, its common sense really to most here i suppose, (like all these things once we’ve seen it demonstrated) but the problem that i was trying to solve was that the main musical element of  the song was a brash bright horns part living in the same range as the vocal, and i was mucking about with all sorts of de-ess/resonant tamer type ideas as it sounded a bit harsh across 3 and a half minutes, but everything i tried, no matter how subtle was taking away from the vocal imo. I wasnt finding a more musical solution. 

Bob, however,  has it in his fine book that i equally could have been having a little dig about in the low mids for the brass parts fundamental (for example) to see where i could add....(as opposed to taking  away up top) ....and then this gives me an alternative route to affecting the brass part and “warm it up “ / re-balance it a bit without having to cut in the vocal. Basic stuff I’m sure for the vets on here. So bob calls this the yin yang....its chapter 4

For me its yet another example of how counterintuitive  the relationship between the problem and the necessary solution can be at first ....in audio engineering . Which i always love discovering a new case of.....on the upwards rise of the learning curve. Whenever anyone casts a pearl I’m grateful .....

author: Iwan Morgan
content:
Interesting response by Chris Gehringer in the new MWTM Q+A section: 

*"Dereck, You really hit home with this one.
I’m 99% ITB for over 10 years was well. I was more hybrid earlier on during my conversion period and now mostly all in due to my workflow and client time demands.

I definitely feel like i’m chasing Refs with the same plugins used by mixers and producers sometimes and don’t feel creative but that’s the game lately. I really feel this is the main problem. I’m not really happy when i’m pushed in that direction.
With almost everyone having the same plugins it’s very apparent that most masters in a shootout sound the same now. No surprises there.

Is Analog Better?

I recently bought a Terry Audio CEQ to try and change my sound and it definitely works. It has an amazing sound and color that cannot be found in most plugins. That being said it doesn’t work for me all the time.
Many of the projects i work on are so loud and pushed anything run through analog gear loses the “glue” that is in the digital mix.
I also just got a Sontec MES-432D9D from Make Believe Studios.
It actually sounds like the real thing to me. It has a much different vibe when using it. I find myself using different frequencies from other EQs.
Is That Better? I’m not sure yet but getting good results when i use both of these tools.

I think the most important part of my setup is that I’m very familiar with my plugins and know when to use different ones when necessary (its also so easier to try another one if you’re not sure obviously)
I’m constantly trying to stay fresh and not mail it in.

Not sure if there’s an actual answer for this but i hope i answered some of your question or at least validated our situation.

Chris"*

author: Rollmottle
content:
@Karim Problem statement: It's a must have that when I deliver, I want the track names displayed to clients clean. Which means I have to rename everything I upload to remove the file type and designator (.REF.wav, .4824.wav, MASTER.wav, etc.).

Feature request/nice to have: The ability to either batch rename tracks so I can strip out ".REF.wav" from 10 files at once, or for the uploader to simply ignore the file type (".wav") from the track display so that if my files are named properly, I don't have to do anything in Samply once I've uploaded my files. I can adjust export on my side to accommodate in the latter case.

I didn't get back a version at the native sample rate so I requested at least a 24 bit file that doesn't have its headroom artificially limited. Same version across all platforms is my jam if the version is optimal, but not if we're giving up headroom to fit one platform's spec. If we were making piano ballads, sure...but this is dance-adjacent DJ music with big kicks and grooves...c'mon.

author: jordanmcleod_io
content: I'm no where as experienced as some of the other peeps in here, but have some thoughts. I think you kind of answered your own questions. $10 is crazy low and not sustainable for anyone, I'm not sure what that other engineer could actually be doing besides blasting tracks through Ozone. Since you are already cold emailing, I think your time could be better sent searching out artists who are in need of an ME and get your full rate there. If you took the $10/gigs, they would eventually be dropped anyways as more full rate gigs started coming in. If it were me, I would rather work the word of mouth game through the artists you are DMing and hopefully more gigs stream in that way via other artists, producers, or mixers. Put in the work now creating meaningful relationships and connections that can exponentially grow instead of the label path which seems like a dead end. I've been cold DMing artists with a freebie first song, I just started this month and it's a big numbers game, so I can't say for certain how it will go. But, because of the freebie I gave them, I am now talking with these different artists about mastering an album, an EP, and several singles at full rate. This is rhetorical, but how many cheap label songs would you need to master in order to get the same amount of money? So in short, if it were me, I would spend my time elsewhere creating more meaningful relationships with much more room to grow.

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
I generally don't do that, FWIW. 

The best producers I work for occasionally ask something specific (e.g. "we started putting Bloom on our mix bus, how do you feel once you recall it and start tweaking?"). Or for e.g. a drum bus w/ heavy processing they'll ask if I'm good to work w a stereo stem instead of the multis. But even that's a fairly rare exception. Mostly they've done what they like, they send it how they want to send it, and they want me to mix it.

There's one producer I work for who regularly wants more feedback. I find it hard to give. Because I wasn't there in the room, I don't know the limitations of the session. It's not helpful to try and impose my harmonic vocabulary or arrangement preferences on someone else's, and the sessions are never unmixable even when I don't think they come from an ideal starting point. And on a fundamental level I really don't like telling other people what to do or how to feel.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
From my side I always want to keep working with people -- you never know how the relationships evolve (I know you know this, you are more experienced than me). I just tackle the notes -- it's rare I would ever say it wasn't a great experience. I want to master as many records as I can. At the very most I would let them come back again, say it's not the right fit and suggest someone I know to be a good fit (I've done this before). But always with the art and their vision first, if I truly don't understand it.

That said -- I did get really close to walking on a recent project, we were way down a rabbit hole, I think I legitimately did 15 masters. And we were caught up on dither, comparing to pink noise, etc. It was wild. We got it across the line - but I went way out of what would be constituted by us as what the "mastering role" should say, because the music was great and I thought the artist could understand my perspective. And I think it actually hit, to refocus on the art and feeling. 

It's a fine line. Sometimes I get the impression that I do step out of what is supposed to be said by mastering engineers -- but people seem to connect with that on my side. 

Also if things are going that way I will just stream it to them -- often they are looking for control or are having a hard time making decisions -- something I see in this new crop of record makers who only have ever worked in a DAW. Hard to know without actually knowing the humans

Then again, many many times I get a note and it's great and insightful and I love it

author: James Cronier
content: Totally agree here as far as trying to meet clients  where they're at with odd feedback/requests. It's not my job to educate clients, and it's definitely not my job to tell them how to feel. It is my job to be an affirming creative collaborator and keep my portion of the relay race that is record-making on track. I've found the more I am open to the weird stuff the more I find cool ways to make things sound better. If I really don't understand something a 5min phone call with the artist or producer solves that problem. If things end up not to my taste, fine. If things truly seem to be going off the rails (like the sudden barrage of notes @thegreatcarsoni encountered) I'll often ask for more info: "hey, I see you've got lots of new notes, I'd love to chat and make sure I'm nailing things for you on my end." More often then not that'll result in a pleasent and productive discussion. Sometimes I end up doing the notes, sometimes the concerned party ends up nixing most or all of the new notes. My whole ethos as a mixer (and occasional producer or ME) is to let the artists and producers into my world and process. No secrets, lots of sharing what I'm doing and why when appropriate. People are not hiring me to mix, they're hiring me to be a creative team member. Being open to "crazy" notes and ideas is part of that sometimes.

author: Moses Mastering
content:
Haha, yes! I put all my energy into showing off what’s already there. I don’t worry about “pokey” things—if it pokes, that’s probably what they wanted, so I lean into it and showcase it even more. Nine times out of ten, when I trust my gut and focus on what the mix is doing well instead of trying to “fix” it, the client is way happier.

That’s a little part of my secret sauce! Highlight the things that are screaming, “Pay attention to me!” Unless, of course, the client specifically says, “The vocal is WAY too pokey,” or “The bass is too heavy.” But even then, I’ll tweak things in a way that amplifies the magic instead of shutting it down.

For example, I might boost the top end until the bass feels correct if they say the "bass feels too loud in the way the mix landed"  cause the bass is supporting so many other parts of the song...or adjust the sides or frequency range to smooth out a pokey vocal—without approaching from a ..let me target the vocal. Ill target other things to make that vocal not feel pokey in context because nine times out of ten theres a lot of magic 99% of the time in that vocal outside of the few times it POKES haha.. if that makes any sense. 

It’s all about amplifying the intention for me .. but thats me:) it makes sense to my ears that way.

author: Berlin
content:
Love everything that’s been said from everyone already.. if I may add…

Most folks on the indie side don’t know what a lot of this means.. They just want to know their job is finished. So in conversation you could just ask what they are going to do? Make CDs? Make Vinyl? You know what they need for these things.. they may not.

Also, in regard to deliverables like vinyl premasters or CD DDPs.. sometimes I’ll master something, digital only, and they’ll come back and ask if they NEED a DDP or NEED a vinyl premaster from me. I am always transparent and tell them the truth that they could order CDs and Vinyl with WAVs only and that would be fine, lots of folks do that, but you are back to proofing new masters with the manufacturer now as a QC mastering engineer. You’ll save some money, but if you want, I can do them and you can show up to your manufacturer ready 100% to go. No pressure. Either way will work. Different means to the same end. And that’s the truth.

Most of the time, they have me do it anyway because they want to call it done when they are done with me and not worry about it. High 5s all around.

author: Moses Mastering
content:
I operate as a 'house' that defaults to delivering 44.1 kHz, haha.... 16-bit files for all clients outside of labels, which consistently require both 24-bit and 16-bit files. I work in the highest format provided to me but always send 44.1/16 as the final delivery. Over time, I’ve found this approach minimizes client confusion and ensures smooth communication.

There was a period when I sent both 24-bit and 16-bit files and included a detailed explanation in the email about their differences and applications. However, instead of clarifying things, it often led to more questions, leaving clients uncertain about what to release and where. It became clear that peace of mind is more valuable than technical details for most clients.

That’s why I stick with 44.1/16—it’s still widely accepted and even remains the standard for many major labels. In fact, I do an annual check-in with labels of all sizes—independent and major—to confirm if delivery standards have evolved. As of this today for this year.. they have said.. just keep sending what you send. 

This is based on my experience and isn’t meant as legal or financial advice—just a method that works for me and my clients to keep things straightforward and stress-free LOLLLLL

author: Paris Lee
content: I think with Reference tracks it’s mostly: what makes you *FEEL* good! Not just like, what’s popular, or the loudest thing, or the most technically impressive…what gets you buzzed! Music is energy, a vibe…when you get that feeling of what sounds like a great record to you, that will transfer to your own mastering - when you can fully take the ‘lab goggles’ off when the sound is coming at you, and connect with the track on an emotional level- you’re done mastering the track.

author: Grover
content:
Surely there's something to learn from the history though yes? Cutting is what the profession of mastering used to be and digital is not wholly removed. We can certainly take learnings from our history while embracing modern methods. Cutting good vinyl is also respect for the folks who work on it and the artists who want their music conveyed appropriately across mediums. 

I have no problem making stuff massively loud with zero limiting and small amounts of soft clipping, and still retaining tons of transient peaks. I prefer this sound to heavy limiting at the master stage where the program material audibly hits the limiter and the soundstage and sense of headroom collapses. To me, the limiter is optional, but I do understand many use it before they acquire the skills to work without it. 

That said, I also was taught that in genres where its appropriate (Imagine Dragons, Hip hop, EDM, etc.) that those sounds should go in at the production or mixing stage. At the mastering stage I was taught to do no harm, and only to enhance what was present. In my work pushing more than a few dB into a limiter to affect the groove of a piece does not track with my understanding of doing as little to change the sound as possible. But of course, it all depends on the project. My clients who make very mainstream pop/youtube music don't particularly care if I radically editorialize as long as it sounds good and serves the tune. 

There's also something to be said for music which needs to be quiet. Not all music should be loudenated to within an inch of its life. Not all music needs quiet and intimacy. I think of we hold the pursuit of "the program material's individual requirements to be king" we cannot then also dismiss vinyl as unimportant or say that one MUST always do things a particular way.

author: Rollmottle
content:
I don’t have the volume of work some others here do so I am more likely to have the time others don’t have to send something to outboard. With that said, I am digital 95% of the time. On the rare occasion I use my outboard, it will more than likely be a single. I will always capture the print pre-limiter. And if I need to tweak something, it will be done with a digital EQ.

These days, I’d never do an album where all the tracks go out. It takes too much time to document, extra time to capture, and when the inevitable mix swap comes, extra time to recall, reprint etc. I used to, but it doesn’t scale well if you have any meaningful volume of work where recalls or in flight projects become prohibitive to you handling more than one work stream for multiple clients at once.

author: Rollmottle
content:
I don't know if there's really anything to do to break people who have arrived at mastering with mixer brain. In my experience, it's driven by deep insecurity and the best I can do is hear their concerns, remind them all the great things in their song and indulge the notes without breaking the whole thing or heading down rabbit holes that aren't worth anybody's time. It's often a balancing act "Well, I can't really do on my end that but I can try XYZ to see if that hits what you're feeling" -- even if I know a thing is technically possible. Sometimes that means a song goes to V7 that was done on V1. 

At the end of the day, I think these folks just want to know they are being heard and I'm not certain there's anything you or I could do better that would solve this other than accounting for more time for projects with stakeholders prone to this (aside from raising their rates or dropping them as clients of course).

author: Rollmottle
content:
The things to check vary based on the requested deliverables. If you’re not really doing this regularly, for you, I'd make sure you’re asking up front if there are alts or files for physical releases that you need to account for. Cleans, instrumentals, acapellas, sequence, overlapping crossfades, metadata, PQ sheets, less lims, vinyl, etc. all may start to matter to finalizing something. And if you haven’t accounted for the deliverable and the time it takes to prep and QC in your rates, well you may be in for some pain.

Others may have some of these steps in different spots, but for me, it's roughly:

1. Print approved masters at native sample rate and bit depth.
1a. < Deprecate un-used versions>
1b.  <SRC/dither to any other sample rates and bit depth requested>
1c. <Assemble any physical deliverables>
2. Listen to every single file you’ve printed & check any data
3. Deliver

author: Moses Mastering
content: I rarely will discount for more songs. I have learned the more songs often the "longer" it takes to make them all play nice with each other especially in 2025 where I might get a record that is from the label with 3 mixers, 13 songs over 3 years of single release then ep, then remixed, then all put together to be "the album". I  honestly can never copy and paste settings either 99% of the time from song to song which I think some clients assume, well you dial one in so the rest should be faster. Sometimes the record is super consistent and it is "faster" in theory, but due dillgence is still needed on every song start finish, then if you get the track list or sequence and its a little complicated or they got high energy next to ballads next to high energy etc. You have to manage how that flows as well. SO I find singles are "easy" ...EP are little harder..... LP to get out the door, with each song reaching its potential while feeling cohesive often takes more "time". So no discounts. I will sometimes discount the total budget if the people are good, music is good and the budget is not my normal rate. SOMETIMES though I ask them to save up haha... because most can and most have rarely thought about that.

author: Moses Mastering
content: 100% fades haha.. and if they get specific with fades .... it becomes a print-fest lol... I ACTUALLY started telling clients about three years ago. PRINT EXACTLY how you want it to start and stop. It will save us all time and actually help with LP becuase we have the pacing already which indeed impacts the ears ability to rest, reset, before the next song and where I need the next song to kick in volume wise to feel good.

author: Berlin
content:
I have my Alts in tiers of 3... Half rate for 3 Alts per track, you get up to 3 per track of your choosing, after that it's another half rate for another 3.

mp3s I would call an SRC master, or any file conversion for that fact, and charge for the Hour it takes to prepare and listen. If not a full LP, I charge 1/10 of the hour rate per track. 

I also do this for any deliverable.. DDP, Vinyl Premaster, etc.. Charge for the Hour to takes for each deliverable to prepare and listen/QC after export.

author: Moses Mastering
content: one persons perspective...I just have two flat rates, one for indie and one for label as it takes more time usually to get a project thru the door with deliverables and random talking heads who think the bass is too loud in their 2013 land rover on the bass boost setting that I have to listen too lol... BUT i ran numbers of time vs money etc about 9 years ago.. and the cost of running alts and the benefit of a flat rate vs explaining to clients cost, and nickel and dime or they come back later and then i had to charge etc. Its way easier for me to run it all right awawy and just call it done. You can make plentyyyyy of money by doing this method and you remove friction and the potential fear in their mind that theres always an upcharge. For me this has played out massively over 14 years of client loyalty and peace of mind. Its a time suck  .. i usuall do invoices during this time... ive done assistance etc.. over they years but then its me paying the assistant to run alts which  is not a high level skill and managing them on some level. Long term you can for sure make a killing just doing it yourself and also the client seems to really enjoy knowing its a turn key process. The  main thing for ths is making sure your charging a high enough rate to start with which isnt really "hard" .... its just a matter of presenting the value and sticking to your rate. Customer service is worth a LOT and especially with referrals. Ill get gigs just because of the above method. Time yourslef how long it takes to do the alts, work the numbers and youll find if your charging a "pro" rate.. its not a  problem. Now of course if you dont want to do it.. thats a different conversation and fine, get an assistant. ALSO RX batch and some other programs people mention can make it extremely fast with a few clicks of the button.

author: Rollmottle
content:
The only good reference tracks are the ones you know deeply so you know that what you're listening to in the room is exactly what you expect to hear -- OR, if not exactly what you expect to hear, you know what's off in relation to the room and speakers therein. I could give you mine, but it's pretty personal to me and my tastes, with some I've picked up along the way (Like Beyonce's "Partition" is a good low end and room test).

Never was much on referencing in relation to actual mastering as I don't think it's that useful. It's more important for getting your room and speakers right.

The other thing I'd prioritize is to go be in good rooms so you understand what good is, so you know where the bar is for your own space and work.

author: hebakadry
content: If you don’t cut and you’re not sure... keep the limiting and let the cutter solve the issues.  If you have a relationship with a cutting engineer and want to see what works best, have them send an acetate where they cut a side with the limiter on full blast and the same exact program on another side with it pulled back and make a determination.  Transcribe the sides into your DAW and then flip between them and see what sounds best.  Don’t compare to the digital master…just use your ears.  Good cutting engineers are creative and may do some work to give you the “transparent” cut everyone’s after.  But it does require some crafty engineering and taste.

author: Austin Gordon
content:
Quick question for the folks, here:

How do y'all handle deliverables when it comes to post-approval of the final masters, but pre/post payment? Usually I don't deliver anything until the invoice has been taken care of at the very end, but for a couple of studios that I have an established thing with, there's been this implied sort of expectation that I should go ahead and send the masters, even though the invoice is still currently pending payment. They've been totally fine and trustworthy in the past, so there isn't a concern for non-payment or anything like that, but I don't want to make the relationship weird or send the wrong message to them by withholding until then. I know some people invoice entirely up front and that solves this problem, but I've had almost zero issues up until now going about it this way.

author: Halliemmelton
content:
I always send invoices for indie projects (especially if they’re discounted) up front but I won’t hold a project hostage or anything. If they ask for parts after all is said and done, same thing. 

Sometimes if it’s an indie artist but they’re paying full rate, I will send an invoice when I send the master or when they have approved; I’m a little less easy about it but it also hasn’t bit me in the ass yet, so we’ll see how long that lasts. 

If it’s a label project I always invoice after—and usually wait a bit to be like “if you don’t need any additional parts I can go ahead and send the invoice” and that prompts them to request parts so I don’t have a project floating around in limbo un-invoiced.

But all my regular clients pay straight away nowadays, had a few cases where they'd send me the payment for the project before I've had chance to write up an invoice! 

100% agree with trusting people. But if it's the first time I'm working with an indie artist then I just let it be known I take things up front. Not in a harsh way of course. Reduces so much friction

I've dealt with a couple projects like this in the past which led me to communicating with the client at the time of first round delivery that after three free revisions I will charge $25 per revision. This way you still have some opportunities to make adjustments but if they need more than three revisions, more often than not it was a problem with the mix and not the master.

I feel like when you send this next round of files back you should let them know that this is the last one you can provide without extra compensation for your extra work and time.

author: Paris Lee
content:
When navigating revisions for me (had to go to a rev 3 recently with someone I’d label ‘eccentric’, and had parted ways with the original mastering engineer before me) 
I think the best practice is to always establish what you did verbally from rev to rev, being careful not getting into the weeds of ‘well you wanted me to widen but that kinda affects this and that bla bla…

don’t confuse them..! 

Don’t talk about frequencies or gain reduction numbers or LUFS etc…

Be concise and confirm you performed their notes point by point, and, get a conformation back that- did you actually accomplish what you set out to do?  To what degree? Did you nail two of the three notes? 1 of the three? 3 of 4? Or all of them? 
Whatever it is- this should help them focus and get the conversation so it’s not just them coming back with things that you weren’t even aware of what they were thinking.

author: miguel @ knurlmastering
content:
I try not to change the hardware from song to song. The chain I create for each record defines the sonic character of the entire project. If I need track-specific adjustments, I’ll add plugins before the hardware chain. That way, each song is shaped to fit the chain I designed for the record. After the hardware, I will add plugins as well, typically something like limiting.

In the end, every song is tweaked individually. Often there are plugins for specific sections, along with level automation within the track. Once those adjustments are made, all songs then run through the hardware chain.

I always print the hardware chain, so when revisions come up (making something a little louder or quieter, or adjusting a fade-in or fade-out) I don’t need to recall the hardware.

author: Rollmottle
content: Not really. If it's the vinyl pre-master based on your digital master, you'll have no idea how that translates to the pressing without hearing the pressing. If it's a digital capture of the test pressing or acetate, you'll have no idea whether what you're hearing is in the actual cut or the equipment used to record the cut to send to you. You'd need the physical test pressing or acetate to actually evaluate how the digital master is translating.

author: peterlabberton
content:
@Nomograph Mastering we’ve had some discussions on here to this effect in the past, but I’m curious your perspective:

I’ve been sending out mixes over the last ~6 months that are only barely backed off my ref mixes for clients. Basically Pro-L2 is my final stage, and if it’s only grabbing a few dB on the ref mix, I might just send that off as is. Or if it’s ended up more aggressive I’ll pull it back and usually end up with it grabbing maybe ~3dB on loud drum hits, maybe more here and there. Essentially aiming to keep some of its effect on drum transients but leave the rest of the track alone. I’ve gotten no complaints from mastering folks and it seems like many mixers are doing this (?)… When you get mixes like this (assuming they’re good enough mixes), are you banging your head against the wall and significantly compromised in your work, or do you just get to work and master the record?

author: masteredbyjack

Not sure why that would happen (though I suspect Ruairi would know) but something I’ve been finding useful is using Samply with clients to approve masters…and if there is indecision about how loud the master should be turning on the “loudness matching” algorithm. They having a loud master play right next to a more dynamic one.

It approximates what happens with streaming (minus the codecs and stuff) and at least you can see, sort of, how a really loud master would sit against a more dynamic one. From a creative perspective so people get an idea of the trade off between density and dynamics. 

However, I am quite new to the pro mastering side of things and while so far my projects are translating as expected I’m very interested to learn more about this and hear others perspectives

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I’ve found this doesn’t work with Automator (or similar key click/command tracking software) for a lot of reasons…it doesn’t capture delays perfectly, thus causing edits down the line to be messed up because it keys them too fast. Ideally you could export a history of edits as a document and apply but that functionality doesn’t exist as far as I am aware.

How exactly are you using it? @Rollmottle and I discussed before but I still haven’t hit on a satisfactory solution. 

But the @Bonati12461 tip could be a great replacement for those edits. Do the edits get saved as automation somehow? So if we have to do a mix revision with a new file we could replace the old one and edits would be saved and applied to new file?

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Wanting to zoom out since there is a lot of software specific stuff recently here…

What is everyone focusing on in the upcoming year?

For me, on the human side it’s continuing to grow the number of projects but also nurturing those relationships better than I have in the past. And overdelivering for people while maintaining a healthy long-term balance in my life

On a technical side it’s taking specific time to dive deep on topics (currently EQ) in a very specific and targeted way for learning but keeping my mastering time very free and intuitive. Only working with things I really understand and come second nature. 

From a philosophical side it’s continually making sure my decision making is based in curiosity and respect for the music rather than fear or concern with how my work is judged

Would love to hear what others are feeling since we have such a wide range of engineers here!

author: Rollmottle
content:
i take the 1 master to rule them all approach so the approval on the digital master is the approval on the master that will be used to cut from. what you get back from the vinyl mastering process, be it in the form of a lacquer or a test press would be up for QC to see how the cut fared. notes would go back to the cutting engineer to adjust. what i wouldn't do, is PRE-adjust the digital master or provide some other version of the mix to "guess" at the moves needed to be made to translate a mix/master onto vinyl. i leave that in the hands of the cutting engineer.

i think the reality is, most vinyl now is a "flat cut" from whatever you send them unless you're working with an ME who is also the cutting engineer, who can shepherd the entire project across the finish line.

I'm nowhere near the level that most others are here...but I send both a Samply link for listening and use Dropbox for the deliverables and tell the client which is best used for which. People seem to like it and it's pretty seamless -- Samply allows an easy player and Dropbox allows easy downloads and clear file structures when needed (and allows you to switch out and add to uploads if ever needed for the same link, links don't go bad, etc). Had a project where we put up the masters and the mixing engineer bounced a wrong version of an alt (I couldn't tell this on my end due to the nature of the alt). But the link had already been sent to client. We were able to switch out the file seamlessly before the client listened via Dropbox and all was okay

And to @Gerhard Westphalen point...if I ever fill up my very large dropbox allowance it probably means I'm rolling in dough and the cost of the extra storage is worth the overhead.

Also question for @Gerhard Westphalen and everyone else:

How are you doing alt versions for EP and albums?

I’m in Wavelab, and I’d like to just line them all up after the current tracks (it is easy to apply spacing and fades to multiple clips at one to ensure the alts are exactly as the mains).

They had another studio also master the album (they hired me because that studio didn’t have availability but ended up having availability). author: Rollmottle
content: I abide by a "One master only" philosophy with the exception being a potentially quieter one for vinyl. The “technical advantage”, to my early mastering ear is nonsense. Make great feeling stuff, who cares if it gets turned down or up

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I take the "whatever we need to do approach", but I've had times where it's totally unreasonable (but on the client side I'd never let them feel that, I remain very encouraging and nice).

But I am in start-up mode and trying to overdeliver. I also use RX a lot and it is generally a massive headache if it keeps going, or the mixes were in rough shape and a lot of RX needed (I find it's generally in this case that there are mix revisions being sent -- the better mixers just have it right and clean from the jump)

If I was in Ruairi's shoes there is no way I could allow what I am currently...but in my case I try to have a convo with them, lovingly, and see why they are sending so many revisions in the first place (generally fear/insecurity and an inability to commit to ideas) and see if we can't have some growth in the long-term mindset too. But very important to feel that one out and know if it's the right situation to challenge a little bit

author: matthewrederburg
content:
I have a silly question for all the mastering engineers out there. Is it bad form to hire a ME to work on material that will never see a release?

The majority of my current work is recording/mixing live sessions for a radio station, an endeavor that has no budget or consideration for the mastering stage. I’m looking to build a relationship with a mastering engineer and it would be well worth it for me to pay for a few masters myself, in lieu of any actual client, in order to find a mastering engineer that I like.

The mixes sent will likely be from my work on these live sessions. It’s contractually fine for me to send this material for mastering, but nobody is asking for it and therefore none of the mastered material will be released.

tl;dr I want to pay professionals for services but I’m worried that the context is weird. Am I good?

author: matthewrederburg
content:
I freelance outside of my radio job. These projects are more likely to make it to mastering. My work history leaves me unable to recommend a mastering engineer to clients when they ask, and I'm looking to change that.

The radio recordings go like this:

1. Record artist performing live
2. Edit and mix for broadcast
3. Sessions gets broadcast. This is the primary "release" of the material
4. Copies of lossless mixes get sent to artist after broadcast. They do with them what they like, including the possibility of release. My involvement here amounts to no more than a credit.

I mention these radio recordings because they represent the bulk of my recent work, and they happen within a fixed process with no consideration for mastering. I started this job without a working relationship with a ME, and the scope of these sessions don't enable me to ever send my work to mastering engineers. Nobody is paying for it basically. I'd love to though!

To answer your question @Nomograph Mastering , the material sent for mastering would have already reached all of its expected stages of release. I would only be hiring a mastering engineer to work on it so I may hear their work. The mastering is for me, not the radio station or the artist - it just so happens that these live session mixes are the most frequent and current projects I work on.

It's a weird situation and that's why I ask the question. I'd just like to be able to recommend a ME to future enquiring clients, and seeing as I have no recent history with any mastering engineer, hiring them to work on the material I have seemed like the best way to get to know their work.

Whew. Appreciate your time. That was really hard to chew through for some reason.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I don't see the reason to master these recordings, they have lived their life. They are mixed on the fly and there are no stakes, no client.

author: cian riordan
content: I may not have your reps, but I have yet to have an album come across my desk that I prep for vinyl that doesn’t sound better with 5 dB less limiting. I get that our line of work is constantly trying to shovel shit rolling down the hill at us, but I think there’s more nuance than “modern records are loud and need to stay loud otherwise they fall apart.” Vinyl isn’t a medium that was designed with -7 or -9 LUFS in mind… and I have yet to hear a vinyl pressing cut in this contemporary fashion that doesn’t sound like a pile of assholes. I have lots of time for serving the client and the project, being a team player and getting things across the line.. but that’s usually the reality of the business... not what’s best for the Sonics. I think vinyl has the opportunity to sound amazing but modern mixing AND mastering techniques are often getting in the way of that.

author: hebakadry
content: If you have a relationship with a cutting engineer and a project with a budget for example…have them do a dub either on a song (both cut in the same spot on each side) or a whole side…with limiting and without…or a few dB less where the dynamics remain intact.  And see how you feel about it.  Or run it through simulathe and preview how it sounds on various playback cartridges.

author: Reedy
content:
Reading this has reminded me of a horror story I had earlier this year with a client / mastering engineer. It's hardly relevant but I'd like to share it as it's public forum and I'm curious if other people have gone through similar experiences. 
I said to client I could master the record, they said they had read online that the mixer should never master the record and to get a different mastering engineer. I said sure, but I would be happy to give them a test master to compare against the master from the engineer. Sent it off to mastering with the mix, test master and stems for stem mastering. Mastering engineer came back and had *completely changed the character of the record*. Did not sound like the mix I had done and definitely didn't sound like the test master I had done (which was mainly a louder version of the mix). Fine if it doesn't sound like the test master, but not fine if it didn't sound like the mix. We must have sent it back to this guy 3 times and every time it returned the same wildly different character. I told artist let me have another go at the mastering, they agreed and I did another master. All was good until the client brought it into their car and apparently there was something really wrong with the master... To this day I still don't know what exactly was wrong, I tested and tested and did absolutely everything I could to eliminate the problem the artist was talking about, but I couldn't hear the problem they were talking about and every time I changed stuff and sent it back to them to test, the main issue at hand was still there. In the end, they went with the mastering engineer's master. I didn't care that they went with someone else, I cared that my mix work was undone and I went above and beyond to try and repair it and it was all for nothing. Kick in the teeth is that it wasn't really that great a record either and I did far too much work for something I should have declined to work on in the first place.
