author: Rollmottle
content: i play it by ear. usually it's relatively minor stuff and it's an "easy" re-cut (nothing easy when you rely on RX) and thus not a big deal to just redo. in the two recent examples you described, those sound like substantial enough changes that you might consider them whole new masters. depends on everything...your relationship to the artist/mixer, the amount of time it would take to redo, your schedule, etc. there's not an easy one-size-fits-all answer IME.

author: Zach Hughes
content: Word. Makes sense. These two examples I just rolled with it and did what needed to be done w/o involving the client further, but I now feel more wary of receiving, in the future, files altered in diff ways than whats been described.

for what it's worth,

I got a lot of push back from the ME on some notes I had. thought something weird was going on in the midrange and the highs but he insisted that was baked into the mix. 

he later proceeded to to tell me his chain which included 2 multiband comps among some other things and refused to take them off when I suggested it. 

someone offered to do me a solid and redo the mastering free of charge. I passed the message to the artist but they insisted he HAD TO do it since they had already paid and weren't getting a refund + he's a good friend of theirs. 

didn't want to create a big argument with the artist in the chat (ME ignored my calls)  so I told the artist to take some time and listen and if they're honestly happy with how it sounds, they should go ahead and approve it - which they did.

I'm a little bummed out. especially cause I really believe in the artist and what theyre doing and took the gig with quite a bit of loss on my end but like you all said, this has all been a learning experience. on my end I feel like I need to learn how to express my expectations a bit better to artists who might not be well versed on the technical side (their words, not mine).

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Okay crew got a question on a scenario I’ve come upon often enough to ask:

A limited REF is given at 24 bit — but when the non-lim mix is given in 24bit it’s peaking at exactly 0.0db. 

Obviously there could be many explanations for this (if intentional, which is fine). But I’ve had it happen quite a few times where I have a close relationship with a mixer and thought it could be an oversight for reasons specific to each instance (not just generally seeing a peak of 0)— turns out when the non-lim 32 bit print is sent there are sure enough overs in there.

Typically i see it happen when they are going into limiters hot in the REF, obviously when they print non-lim there are overs. Talking big overs, +4db or whatever

BUT — honestly it doesn’t really sound “clipped” in the 24bit non-lim print — I’m assuming the overs are just recalibrated to zero but somehow this doesn’t sound bad? Of course, if I get the 32bit I find I can make it sound just as loud but “better” with the full waveform represented in the 32bit file.

It’s an easy fix — just get a 32 bit print without a limiter (if I can get in touch with who is handling that, which isn’t always the case).

I think (?) I understand what’s happening — DAWs operate at 64 or 32 and can handle the overs fine in the session, but upon render at 24bit they get chopped (not sure about wording).

Totally fine — I can and have handled it no problem, just a curiosity on what others are seeing, if I’m even on the mark about this and how (or if) you are handling it.

content: Tbh I would just always request 32 regardless yeah?

author: itMIGHTbeNICK
content:
What do you guys do in situations where you're being asked for a mastering revision when the notes are mix notes and not mastering notes.

Context: I mastered this track where the vocal was clipping by the main hook of the song, gave myself some headroom and got to work and was able to lighlty fix it with some EQ and some RX. Got a call... Hey man it feels like the kick isn't sitting right in the mix, the vocals sound a little peaky overall, and it sounds like the song as a whole just isnt as dynamic as the mix. I let him know exactly what i did and he proceeds to talk with the artists and then tell me they will give me a new mix. 
Mix two, the vocals weren't loud enough throughout the track and yet again was asked what I did in the master to make this happen and why the vocals sounded compressed.
Was then told yet again that this was a mix issue.

We are now on "Final mix 4" and i'm hesitant to even send off another master at this point.

author: Rollmottle
content:
Are stems not a standard mix deliverable nowadays? Figured it was and assume it’s priced in. Time to raise your rates?

Stem mastering is definitely a thing and the norm in certain genres. I’ve only done it in the rarest of cases as a problem solver, not because it’s better or preferred (I think it’s worse, but it is a tool). This isn’t always possible for every project but this is where having relationships with ME’s you trust come in to play so you can include the master as part of your deliverable to ensure the integrity of the mix.

author: Rollmottle
content: Also, the key to a mentor-mentee relationship is that it’s actually valuable for both of you and you both can commit the time to it. 3-5 can be an aspirational goal over the long term, but man, that’s a lot! I’d aim for finding and developing one great one.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Best practices question: 

I sent out a bunch of finished, approved, dithered mixes to a client and then they told me the song order sequence and wanted me to tighten up the transitions, so I loaded those dithered mixes up and trimmed tops and tails. I imagine since I didn’t add any processing (other than one imperceptible fade) and I already randomized the bottom bit in the previous project that I should be good to export and ship as is, but are there any reasons why it would have been functionally better to have done tops and tails on the undithered file and applied dithering afterwards?

author: Joshua Riley
content:
Main takeaways: 

Always get a second opinion 
Let your emotions cool down before you respond to an artist 

Context: 

An artist I work with regularly has a relatively small budget and isn’t the most experienced with the mix/master side. 
Every track I’ve mixed for him, he’s had it mastered for free by an ME. Two songs ago he got onto experimenting with AI mastering which he thankfully moved off of because the tracks sounded horrible. 
This last track we did, he had another ME offer to do a test master on it. I was down and just asked if I could hear it before it goes out. Fast forward, he uploads the track and the first time I hear about it was through socials. So I asked if he went with that ME and how it sounded and got told no, his drummer mate ended up mastering the track. 
So I just got quite frustrated as him and I have quite an open relationship. Mainly because it didn’t sound that great. There was a bunch of true peak overs which thankfully I’m less stressed about after speaking to Jack
So I’m struggling to see if this is ego or just that I don’t trust this person who mastered the track.

author: Nick Stetina
content:
@masteredbyjack (sees the post time) I can’t tell if you pulled an all nighter or woke up wildly early on a Saturday 😄

Has there been a discussion with the client on what the end destination is for this release and/or expected deliverables are? Great to have worked on and captured the original mixes as masters in their native sample rate, but if this is going to a DSP for streaming, its SRC your masters from the high-res 48k capture to 44k for submission that I’d be focused on, instead of the other way around (upsampling the original 44.1k master to 48k). If the 48k files didn’t get rejected at upload I’d hate to find out what their algorithm sounds like 😬  Better the devil you know, imo.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I’m an early riser haha. Goggins life.

So update — turns out we do have the 48k of the initial so that’s all cool. And I’m close with the producer, so we need 48k and 44k 16bit deliverables (they requested this). All easy.

So problem solved now — but still curious about if people have delivered projects with multiple sample rates as an exercise in learning

@Nick Stetina it’s going to streaming but my default is to deliver the native sample rate the mixes come in at. Most distros take it almost anything, though I’ve seen more requests recently for 44k 16bit for some of these smaller, newer distros. 

Apple will play it (in ALAC) at what’s delivered, yeah Spotify will covert but it’s making an OGG anyway (which we can check in RX) — so my preference (and I’m open to have my mind changed) is to deliver what it was created and mixed at for a lot of reasons. That seems to do great for me so far! Is there a reason you only do 44 (if I’m understanding that right?)

author: Nick Stetina

I had a project recently where the vibe was very much lofi, DIY recorded jazz/trip hop (think trendy brunch playlist). There was an artifact during the decay of the last hit of the song that felt out of place to me, but contextually, could have been a deliberate choice to keep (players rustling in the live room, knocking a stand kind of thing). The production was ‘messy’, but artfully so. I brought it to the artist’s attention before printing, they checked it out, requested I remove it and were thankful I mentioned it since it slipped past them.

What’s everyone’s typical play in that situation? Leave it and assume it was intentional, ask the artist, or just zap it without remark. I recognize there’s a bunch of factors that would influence the approach …in this instance it was a first time client, indie, 1:1 contact (no mgmt or CCs).

author: Nicky Howard
content:
ADM is a strange one. Shouldn't this have become obsolete when lossless became available?

As I understood it, the purpose of ADM (originally MFIT) was to provide listeners with a closer representation of the source after encoding to Apples lossy format, and help mitigate artefacts like ISPs from the process.

If the listener has access to a lossless version, after decoding this is the source.

I've clients still request this as they just like the badge, and the ADM bonus cash is always welcome.

author: Berlin
content: i’ve had tracks that requested ADM compliant files that didn’t get the badge, and tracks that didn’t request ADM compliant files get the badge. 🤷‍♂️ always been like that. of course the opposite is true too.

author: Nick Stetina
content:
+ @Rollmottle , you know what, poor word choice on my part by saying “undoing”, haha. What I really meant was in the event of a revision request. 

For example, I worked on a song this week with a jazz quartet instrumentation and a singer with a bit of a lisp. Super dynamic mix, the upright bass had a lot of wild moments that needed to be reigned in. Always gonna follow my gut on the to first pass, but also recognize the singer’s potential sensitivity to how their lisp comes across on the recording. I just opted to focus on the instrumentals on the first pass in RX, save the file, duplicate it, then work from that and focus on vocals. They approved on the first pass, but if I had to go back to the drawing board on the vocals, for example, I did not want to have to go through every note plucked on the upright bass again and would be thankful to have that ‘RX_INST’ file on hand.

Which I guess brings up another workflow question: are you splitting focus when in RX and doing multiple passes, or just play through once addressing whatever it is you hear as you go?

author: Conah Tucker
content:
Hey there how's it going!

Just wanted your thoughts on advice on something I'm currently trying to tackle with my own mastering buisness.

Currently on my 2nd year, and at the moment I'm contacting lots of UK dance/electronic labels to try get some consistent work coming in. All is well until the majority of labels I contact all get mastered by the same engineer who charges £10 a track, which I think is such a low rate and seems like a race to the bottom.

Is it worth it at my stage to take on these lower paying gigs? 

My thoughts are:
- It could be damaging to the clients I already work with that pay my full rate.
- These bottom clients will never be full rate if they've had a £10 deal for years
- It gets more work in for me = my name gets spread out a bit more. But, these labels never seem to credit the mastering engineer.

What are your thoughts? What would you do?

author: Conah Tucker
content:
Yeah fully get where you're coming from! Just frustrating because I've spent all this time building relationships with these label owners etc, which always gets shut down at the last hurdle because my rate is significantly higher than the £10/$10 they're currently on. 

The upside that I'm seeing is that it might be cheap work, but it gets some money through the door. Gone full time into mastering at the start of this month (using the money I've saved for gear as rent money essentially buying me time to grow the buisness) so money wise is pretty scary.

Definitely going to pivot what I'm doing and head down the artist/producer/mixer route, you're completely right. Feel like I've wasted a load of time connecting with these small dance/electronic labels.

author: Conah Tucker
content: Yeah completely understand where you're coming from. I guess there's no harm taking on these clients for now as I'm only mastering 5-10 tracks a week, so I do have the time in my schedule to do these lower paying gigs. As time goes on I'll be able to fizzle them out if they don't pay full rate Do you think this will be a good route to go down for now or is it still more harm than good?

author: Conah Tucker

author: Nicky Howard
content:
Hi all! I have a question for the collective mind. In many vocal mixes I receive (even from seasoned mixers/producers), there are small clicks between phrases. 

Hopefully, someone with a bit of extra know-how can shed some light on the cause? 

I have my suspicions, but it's a bit out of my depth. 

I'd love to be able to offer advice on this to clients and potentially save years of RX time.

author: Nicky Howard
content:
I completely agree with you that it would be impossible to give feedback on all the different artifacts encountered.

This is more specific. There must be a cause—something like a common vocal plugin or interface that would at least be helpful to advise clients that it could create this. Prevention rather than the cure.

It's like a periodic set of hairline clicks after each phrase. I'm hearing it much more regularly, which is why I wondered if anyone else had encountered it.

I started mastering before RX, and it's now a fully integrated part of the process. Some people certainly choose not to take this route, which is cool if it works for them. 👍

author: Will Pragnell
content: I'm too new to the mastering game to have something to share from that side, but I have sent a lot of my own music to be mastered and always ask for mix notes... my motivation in doing so is always to try to tap in to the fresh (hopefully objective) ears of the ME and see if I can hear something new in the mix that I missed, and turn that in to learnings for better mixes in the future. This is for music that I write, produce, record, and mix all myself, so by the time a mix is done I'm usually way too close to it and have lost all sense of perspective. I imagine if I was a fully fledged mix engineer mixing tracks for producers/artists I'd feel less of a need to do this. Not sure if that perspective is helpful... but maybe?

author: Will Pragnell
content: This is making my head spin a little. I'm not disagreeing with any of the above, but I'm struggling a little to reconcile it with my experience as an artist who has sent mixes off for mastering, asked for notes, and genuinely wanted to be told if there was something like "the kick seems 6db too loud" so that I reevaluate, see if I missed something, think about why that happened, and maybe send a new version of my mix. It feels strange to me to have this perspective as a client (i.e. this is the service I hope to get and am paying for) and then on the other side of the relationship say something like "don't provide this information, even though they asked for it, just do the best master you can". There's a mismatch there that _could_ be interpreted as the ME not providing the service the client wants. Perhaps the contextual difference here is that when I was sending these mixes to mastering, it was not my "career", I didn't have a team, or deadlines, or a label involved. Or perhaps I'm just misunderstanding?

author: Will Pragnell
content: For sure. There's a skill to working with clients, figuring out what value you can provide to them, understanding what they actually want vs what they say they want, etc.

author: Will Pragnell
content: I understand this. The core part of the mastering service is to finish the record, ensure quality, and make it the best version of what it can be. To counter, though, if I explicitly hire an ME and say to them "the reason I'm choosing to pay you for mastering is because I want the mix feedback" (which is something I have 100% done in real life), then the definition of what the service is maybe isn't quite as clear cut

author: Will Pragnell

A project is basically just a list of files. You hit share and it creates a player for all those files. But let’s say you wanted to just send a few of those files- you’d select those and send them. One project, but two different players.

The thing we found is that most pros have your workflow^ it’s just one link with all the songs in it, and they’re using something else to send the deliverables. So they’re not using stacks, folders, or any of the other file management-y tools in projects.

I’ve recently been getting some feedback on mix + masters and recurrence has been that chorus’ and bigger sections of songs need more stereo width. There is major panning already happening within these tracks… so I’ve been trialing out imaging tools such as S1 imager, Ozone Imager, T-racks imager, Microshift & Doubler. I’ve been starting to play with M/S eq and have been having some small wins - but would appreciate and thoughts, views, opinions or direction!

Thanks team 🙏🏼

author: nachomaquieira
content: Hi everyone! Today I thought I’d write here to ask how you approach mastering an album that you've mixed yourself. Sometimes I work on albums where the mixes are done in a very short time, and other times it takes longer, so the focus changes over time (which is totally natural). Right now, what I’m doing is setting up a mastering session with all the latest mixes (with limiting applied), doing the track list, and listening to the differences between them—things like timbre, balance, loudness, etc. I make notes of what I hear, then go back to the mix sessions to make small tweaks. After that, I export everything without the final clipping/limiting on the tracks, so I can apply those in the final mastering session and then master the album. Anyone with a different approach is more than welcome to share, as right now I’m wrapping up a lot of albums I’ve worked on throughout the year, and I want to stay as sharp as possible to give them a proper finish.

As far as the tech goes, it is available! It can be build. I can build it. It's just a matter of time & resources (people, money, files, hardware). But the people building it are not doing it correctly. It's a fast-grabbing cash machine for the inexperienced.

The thing that people are not taking into account when it comes to mastering is trust. No matter how good of an app you build you cannot have the same level of trust & relationship. 

When people come to me for mixes, or you for mastering, they don't come and say "hey can you do a serban mix?", they trust OUR TASTE. They have a relationship with us. They have a sense of security.

author: Will Pragnell
content: How much are people worrying about mono compatibility in 2025? I know that many small bluetooth speakers, etc. are still summing to mono, so it feels like it matters to me. That said, I'm noticing a lot of recent releases that seem not to care. Latest example is https://tidal.com/browse/track/371179904?u - huge chunks of the strings just dissapear in mono, and looking at a correlation meter while it's playing I can see that it's negative a lot of the time. Would you have let this go out like this? How do you approach it if you get a mix like this? (edit to clarify: not asking about the technical side of how to fix this sort of thing, asking about how you think about this kind of stereo material, how you approach it with clients if you feel it needs changing, etc.)

author: Will Pragnell
content:
Great question. Let me try to answer. I suspect this may be where the learning opportunity lies...

I think what matters to me is that 1) the piece is presented in the best way possible to maximise its impact or essence 2) the piece is listenable and that impact is not lost in a wide range of environments / contexts (i was tempted to say "it translates well" but I think that's a subtly different thing) 3) the client is happy with the result, and feel confident releasing their art, feeling good about it, feeling it's the best version of what it could be.

I think it's point 3 that gives me pause. You can count my paying mastering clients on one hand, so I'm as "beginner level" as it gets, but that said, when i talk to those clients, they share with me that they want a mastering engineer to ensure that their music is going to "sound right on streaming platforms and translate well to lots of systems". There's a lot of FUD about loudness normalisation, LUFS, etc. I don't think it's a huge leap to feel that we should also be thinking about common playback devices such as airpods, and bluetooth speakers. For clients who aren't seasoned mixers or record makers, I wonder how they would feel if they listened to their mastered record on a bluetooth speaker and heard that whole parts had practically vanished. Of course I'm also sensitive to not wanting to introduce doubt in their minds unnecessarily.

author: Berlin
content: Back when VRP was still going and I was cutting lacquers and QCing TPs daily. Alot of the notes that would come back regarding playback quality, I'm gonna say 99% of them, had to do with the clients own playback system. Of course, an issue of our own doin would come up here and there, but often it was that the client/label/manager was just listening more critically than they ever have before and were just noticing issues inherent to their system which they had never noticed before. AB with other pressings/works always helped shine a light.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Big Picture - Sometimes clients give us notes that are to our understanidng obviously wrong. "Hey the bass is distorting" and say we know that that the speaker in their car stereo is busted from the last time we rode in their car. The reflex is to say "no, the master is fine, you are wrong". But if we listen better what they are really saying is "I don't feel like we're finished yet"

author: Berlin

author: Moses Mastering
content: Normally when they "hear" what I have done ... and this is gonna be tooting my horn... they go.. wait .. we didn't know the mixes could elevate to that level, can you mess with the other ones... AND sometimes they just end up having me remaster it from the mix as well and that replaces the original single that already came out on the DSP... the work usually speaks for itself. BUTTTTTT if i get the previous masters and then the next 8 mixes that need mastered and they go ...just do the next 8. The conversation is honest. Its ... those previous 3 are going to sound dull and less full next to the 8. So we have a choice, I try to dull down the potential of the 8 to fit those 3 or you let me take a run at those 3 to match the new 8. Sometimes they.. go.. lets hear 1... then they go.. OKAY ya.. sometimes they go.. NEVER thought about that... good point .....we want it all to be the best it can be so do what you need to do. The confusing part is later in the credits .. when i have to send muso the proof i did it and not the other ME who clamied it.... lol turns out the labels dont go back and tell other ME they didnt get the final master ....also i have mastered things i dont have credit on which sucks.. but politics... but i know the "right" people know who did what so thats all that matters to me. keep getting hired and paid haha. thats what i care about lol. All the above is said much more elegantly and you are right bedside manner is key.

author: Grover
content:
Bob and Ian's opinions on "audiophiley" music are of no functional interest to me. I'm not advocating for that in either digital or vinyl mastering. 

And I get it - I know and have worked with several really talented and very busy cutting engineers, and I take it seriously as well. 

A question was asked regarding how to prepare masters. A good friend of mine is one of the top Lathe techs in North America, and my understanding from him and the cutting engineers I know and have worked with, is that digital clipping can make life hard for lathes. I'm not saying you cannot do it or arguing the merits of digital limiting or anything like that, that's an entirely separate topic. It is however a technical fact that lathes do not get along well with digital clipping and it will make the cutting engineers job harder and generally result in a record which does not sound as dynamic. If that is an acceptable compromise then so be it. As you say, if the artist/client is happy and the bills are paid, then all is well (mostly 😉)

author: mcsnare
content:
Hip hop is almost unique in the limiting being a huge technical aspect of the genre. I continue to master hip hop although I have not as of yet, cut any. 
My standard procedure for making a digital master for lacquer cutting is simply to render the sides without limiting. 
Ive have had exactly one client that thought the test pressing sounded too dynamic so I resent the files but with some limiting retained although not the full monte. If you heard the music you would have NEVER guessed this twist in the story. 
@hebakadry is correct that highs are a bigger deal. I guess the point is every project has unique characteristics that require the person cutting it to sometimes make decisions that blur technical and artistic ones together. This is partly why I have a policy of cutting only masters I’ve done. I feel I have the liberty of eq’ing some more at cutting time. 
So as far as the comments go, nobody is totally wrong - it’s simply very situation dependent. I would advise a few things:.

author: mcsnare
content: Having an extreme, AudioFile level of vinyl playback is part of my experiences. I sometimes want the record to sound better than even the client does!

author: mcsnare
content: That is one perspective. And I’m past caring about working with clients chasing that kind of pop success. I work on a lot of stuff I’m happy to make very loud - 9 db of soft clipping is not super rare for me. But if I had to go that extreme me AND the client agree it sounds better either way less or none. I’m probably working in a different group of folks than you are. I did my time mastering the Serban albums and I’m into a different thing theses days.

author: Grover
content: I'm not sure what "peeling back limiting" means exactly. But I would say that if the client asks for -9LUFS then that is the job, to make it -9LUFS. If they want -14LUFS then that is the job. And in doing so only to pass through as transparently as possible what the creative team has done. The challenging part in mastering is that at a very minute level all of the tools a mastering engineer has do affect the sound. The skillful balance thereof is what makes the craft fascinating fun and challenging. I suppose I was a bit caught off guard by Nomograph's positing that heavy limiting at the mastering stage to affect the groove (maybe I misunderstood that comment) is pretty much the standard. I don't find that much limiting to be very transparent personally. Doesn't make it wrong. clients are free to work with whomever does work they like best, as you say.

author: Elaine Rasnake
content:
I completely agree and that's why I usually will ask if it was intentional with as much kindness and positivity towards the choice to make sure we're both on the same page.

author: Paris Lee
content:
Gaining trust with the artist is so important 
If Artists are in LA (when I have time) I always encourage them to come to my studio to play their mixes. When they’re in my environment, I find it’s easier to have conversations on the record, and what Im feeling about it and what they feel about it . Even a phone conversation, not even about the track necessarily, but just shooting the shit and them getting to know you, helps a TON with these types of situations when come up. 
Human connection is everything in the service industry. A lot of people are too busy to talk. And in some cases for legitimate reasons. My clients appreciate that they can reach me, text me etc without dealing with middlemen. When a client feels like they’re sent something off and aren’t getting what they expect out of communication, and THEN getting back something they don’t like. THATS where things go left! 

I don’t get fired that often, but like a breakup in a way, I can predict in the way we are communicating pretty much 90 percent of the time that it’s not gonna work out for whatever reason

author: Paris Lee
content: The thing that I never, ever, ever, want to hear from a client is ‘you changed my mix’. We have a lot of leeway to push and pull a track in the way we want to (which can be a little or a lot), but the fundamental mix still has to be there, just ‘better’, however better is to be defined. As @Nomograph Mastering said, the music will dictate how you steer the ship and put your stamp on the record.

author: Paris Lee
content:
A joy to listen to. It has a mellow sheen that’s got a perfect presence  that does *not* digititis mix elements from 3-10k. *Especially percussive ones*
That hot bright snare sample that kicks up your anxiety level and inflames your tinnitus asserts itself as being what it is, but is free of those extra panic attack additives

You are unshackled-less afraid to eq certain areas that evoke ptsd that other converters have baked into you. That 8x oversampling setting might be wrong, but the aliasing is not fucking up your whole day and making you reach for a Xanax 

Very easy to concentrate on the music and feel relaxed doing it. No notes. 

We’ll see if the benchmark stays. Not part of the ‘master plan’ i just don’t have trs xlr cables for the other RME da pair. 
But we all know the DAC 3 kicks ass so no complaints at all pitching with it right now…

author: Circul & Eas
content:
It's great to hear these experienced perspectives. It's not usually what I 'want' to do , honestly. I want to create those honest feedback relationships, or at least open the dialogue and ask about certain issues, talk with the mixer/artist about what they want, etc, in order to dig in a bit more. But I'm recognizing that this kind of approach also ends up digging holes into my pay-to-time-spent-working-on-a-project ratio. And I do see the point that what people usually actually want from a ME is someone who will take their baby and make sure it's all good and just help them get it out the door. 

I feel like I want to make thing more complicated and context-dependent. But many of you are saying that I should mostly treat this like emotional support, rather than technical support, in most circumstances. 

It makes me think of how I've learned to turn off my own technically minded 'problem-solving' approach to life issues when I'm trying to support my wife - who just gets annoyed when I try to brainstorm solutions to her problems, and actually just wants to be emotionally supported. I find it super hard to do this, and I have to consciously hold my tongue and say and do all sorts of things to provide her with what she wants, rather than what I would naturally do.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-4EDhdAHrOg

author: Paris Lee
content:
I just mastered a song with a slammed mix and slammed to hell ref, mixed by one of the main assistants of a mixer who is a household name. 

I said nothing. Had doubts that the level was right for the track, but the mix i got had all what i felt was not my ‘taste’ baked in anyway…

So time to flip the burger…
Delivered it a half db lower than the ref -6.7 LUFS integrated, but eliminated the rumble they missed, slightly widened (like 2 percent) above 100-200hz somewhere,  narrowed below 14 percent for a more focused feel of the slam drum impact while the width was allowed to breathe…and some eq…
Referenced the ref. Felt it felt better sent it back. 

Producer liked it and then comes the classic ‘well what did you think it was too slammed?’ Then we kinda fall into the conversation…”i mean…i dunno…the loudness of the ref was a lot…i might not have gone that much…” 

which sparks the “no man you do you! Master to where you feel is right! Forget the ref! Should we call the mixer to change it for you and give you more headroom??” 
This is where you really have to be careful and really explain it out. Because I don’t know how the mix was constructed. I also know that clients will tell you we want it dynamic till you’re blue in the face, but usually that’s bullshit (not like intentional bullshit…but 8/10 you’ll do it and they’ll want you to make it louder again…)

Where am i going with the this…it’s always important to stress to the client when they ask you ‘can we do better. What do you think. What should i tell the mixer to do…etc…*never* make any guarantees about *anything*. Always preface your statement with ‘unless we actually go through the process of doing it again, we won’t really know! It may, it may not.  That’s really the truth. And lay out the state of play as it is. “If we were to do it again…lay out all the variables that need to be considered- how the mixbus was constructed for one…and stay out of The business of giving the mixer edicts.

author: Ted Whitten Media
content:
When doing revisions, does anyone save a whole new project file with a version number appended to the end? Wondering if that might help me stay more organized. Currently working on an album where the client wanted to go back to V1 for release, and I swear I kept track of every move I'd made to get to v2, but for some reason I just couldn't get it to sound exactly like V1 again. It's no problem on their end because they just used the file I'd rendered and uploaded to Samply. But now I have a clip in my montage that doesn't match the released version, which I don't like. I ended up dropping the master on a reference track instead.

I think this issue was partially caused because I tend to send an initial rough master too early in the process and they get demo-itis. For some reason I've always wanted to send clients an initial rough master after I've done the quick "from the gut" broad strokes, but before I've totally nailed down the nitty gritty stuff, to see if they like the direction I'm headed. And all too often they end up liking the first version.

Or maybe I'm just overthinking v2 and making it worse on a regular basis? I dunno... 😂

author: Rollmottle
content:
I don’t save a whole new session. That seems messy to me. In Reaper you can use their take system to duplicate the wav in place, and it creates a copy inline of the other one (or ones) that can be independently processed from the prior version. So you can have your version history right there and it’s easy to flip back to prior versions and leave yourself notes for each take. Haven’t had the pleasure of going upwards of v15 or something, but has worked well for me even if we’re up to v5, v6. 

Also agree, don’t send a rough master. If a master is definitionally “done,” there should’nt be a rough one.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Let’s say you have a vocal and an instrumental that are both very “unbalanced” in a traditional sense frequency response wise in opposite directions. 

If you make the vocal feel good and human, the overall balance of the record will be very lumpy, and if you make the overall balance of the record sit in a place that feels balanced, the vocal will feel cheap and janky.

I don’t think there’s going to be any hard and fast rules because every record is different and navigating those vibe tradeoffs in relationship to the intention of the music is a part of the job, but I’m curious if anyone has any insights, philosophical or otherwise for this somewhat common occurrence. (Doesn’t have to be about the vocal but it is for me on this album)

author: Halliemmelton
content:
I have a big question and maybe there would be a better “general” thread for it but would love anyone’s insight.

I just remastered an album for an artist—not gonna say who mastered it the first time, the masters aren’t bad and the mastering house has a great reputation—but the new masters are without a doubt more engaging and bring the intent of the record forward a lot more. I think it’s in part because have a more personal relationship with the artist and could dig in harder knowing their intentions.

I’ll lead with—I’m biased af. Not because of my masters or anything, just because of my relationship with the artist and how I want them to do well. 

The single I mastered for the artist did really well streaming, and this previous (imho really amazing, again I’m biased) record had kinda flopped—def didn’t get the attention it deserved, and it got zero playlisting—I’m talking less thank 25k streams compared to the single’s 300k streams. 

I really love the record and do not think it got the chance it deserved. 

The artist loves the new masters, and we’re now chatting about resubmitting these new masters—if we swap out, it feels like there’s zero chance to reconsider playlisting? In theory I know playlisting may not make a difference, but the single’s stream counts make us feel like it’s important enough to consider. The album was released in 2022, so re-releasing it as a different version is definitely an option as well—but curious if any of you have any experience in remasters/rereleases etc and have any opinions or advice on different ways this could be handled!

author: Jasper Boogaard
content:
I think the chance for playlisting here would be a lot higher if there’s a new team/label behind it pushing it to streaming services’ editorial teams. In my experience the label’s PR team is still very important in playlisting and if the remaster gets a new push from a new label that might help a lot.  

if they do a smart repackaging as a deluxe remastered album, maybe add a live version or bonus track, this might help too. They will definitely get another push in the Spotify Release Radar which is a good source of new streams.

author: Edsel Holden
content: I have no business speaking on this with authority - I know nothing about release strat - but when I read your post a "remastered deluxe version" def came to mind

author: Halliemmelton
content: I know people swap out audio all the time, I’ve helped with that before—but never tried to rename it as a remaster, so my knowledge ends there

author: Berlin
content:
Hey there. The only way it would work is if it's an all new release, with new ISRC and UPC and everything.. but even then Spotify may see that it's a previously released track for this artist and not allow it for Playlist submissions. If you share the same metadata, track lengths, etc etc.. if it all looks the same, it will likely not be available to that artist for play listing at all.

So PR, MGMT, Label relationships with Apple, Spotify, etc would be the best fail proof approach I think there. Of if they get a distro deal like with Tone Tree or Symphonic who can help bring new life to the release.

Just leaning on the algos and stuff won't do it in this case, I really thing a human working the release relationally is what it would take.

author: Paris Lee
content:
I’ve said this before on this forum but since we’re back on the subject 
If you’re gonna try to tell the mixer what to do, and can’t back it up on exactly how then don’t say shit. I don’t mix never have, and if i said something it’s inevitably “how do i fix it? And i have no good answer for that… so i don’t do it

BUT…my vibe is being in the room with my clients while we’re working and just explaining my process and what I’m hearing and affecting the audio and it’s WAY EASIER, when they get the idea of what’s happening in a good room, it’s *much^ easier to be on the same page and get into a collaborative groove and give them an open forum and an sense of equality with me -and they feel empowered to speak the fuck up and tell you no no no go back the other direction. If there’s too much sub, they’ll hear it themselves…if it’s bright as fuck…same…
And then to watch you FIX IT, you get clients for life that way
The technology we have to makes this process feasible remotely as well and that’s only going to get better

author: Paris Lee
content:
I got myself, in not  a catastrophic bind,  but a situation that is unfortunately adding more stress to my client than need be- in a very high stakes situation where I have to perform and will be rewarded with a whole host of new opportunities if I do. 

Was approached for a commercial jingle master (and as always, asked exactly when you need this, and adjusted my schedule accordingly with the appropriate wiggle room for anything that comes up. 

Well…shit came up…and it’s my making 

I Was sent the WAV a week ago (one song), told them I’d get to it in a week, and it’s due on Friday. 

Get to the computer today, and alas, it’s a compressed file masquerading as a wav. 

Now, the exec producer behind the song is occupying the studio-with an artist who DOES NOT get interrupted for any reason *whatsoever* 

so they’re going to get me the file as soon as they can, but it’s gonna cut much closer than I wanted it to. 

I converted it to wav and have the master basically where i want it when it comes in.

Totally on me. Could have all been avoided if I just looked at it in RX before tucking it away in the queue.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
(copy/paste)

Assuming we're talking about fairly typical rock, pop and Hip Hop then this 3 part strategy covers a lot of ground

1) Make sure the EQ is as balanced as you can get it - most of your perceived loudness comes from the arrangement and mid range focus (2k to 8k). Too much low end will sound bad when you limit. Make sure the relationship between 80, 160 and 320 makes sense (think of them a little like fundamental, 1st and 2nd harmonic).

2) Consider shaving snare transients (and maybe kick transients) with a clipper. This spreads that peak energy harmonically across the spectrum, keeping energy, hiding in the noisey nature of snares and lets the limiter work less hard (I like SIR Standardclip - $25, great metering and responds intuitively). a dB or two of clipping will help the limiter work less.

3) Pro-L2 on the settings below is a great start point for clean and predictable limiting, raising input gain until you get the desired level

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I think in octaves down there, and it’s rare for me to do more than 2 moves below 200, usually in some kind of octave relationship

author: aliberger
content: hey all, i have a q about order of operations for SRC & bit depth reduction when turning in masters for different formats, which somehow i'm doing for a client for the first time today. the premasters for this project came in at 24/48 except for two remixes at 24/44. i did the digital masters at the original sample rates, they've been approved and now i also need to send 16/44 for a cd and 24/48 as 2 full sides for a tape

author: Berlin
content:
If you want you can implement 2x oversampling to help mitigate ISP a little, but if you wanted a little more control, you can upsample and work at that high sample rate. Export at that higher sample rate, and 32bit float.

SRC and Dither using RX for your various formats.

Reassemble in your DAW for each program. i.e. Main Master, DDP, or Vinyl Premaster.

Find a workflow that works for
you.

Lots of folks don’t worry about these things and just export, listen and party. 🎉

author: Edsel Holden
content: if a re-boucne does nothing to change it then I would clean up the render in RX or clean up the pre-master file in RX. Other things you can try - adding a small fade, moving any automation points you may have around that moment. For me it's usually some combo of them all.

author: hebakadry
content: I do a stem master maybe once or twice a year and it usually comes with a whole host of criteria and questions before I really commit.  Almost always there’s no mixer involved, almost always I have done a stereo version before and they felt the need to go deeper and almost always it’s with a client I know rather well.

author: hebakadry
content: When it’s worked and the client came away super stoked, that makes it all worth it for me.  Lately, most of the stem work I do is with international artists who self mix, where the exchange rate makes it very hard to hire outside mixers, if they’re hard to find for the particular genre they oscillate in.  So even if I wanted to recommend a mixer it’s not really in the cards and I gotta step in and help out.  Which I’m super happy to…when it’s right.
